title: My husband’s boasts are worse since Brexit – and I can’t stand it | Dear Mariella | Life and style
content: Nothing to do with Brexit. It's got everything to do with a lack of respect for you. No matter what the subject, you should never treat a partner with such disregard and disrespect.

title: My husband’s boasts are worse since Brexit – and I can’t stand it | Dear Mariella | Life and style
content: Oh dear, even Mariella has been mandated to shoehorn a brexit theme into her problem pages. Your partner irritates you and has done for 30 years. So what else is new? Why don't you feel able to express your views? Is he bullying or coercive? If not, either agree to disagree or if you're up to it, tell him what you really think and ask him to try to look at things more broadly and to realise that not everyone has the same experience. What is good for one person's circumstances could have a detrimental impact on someone in a different circumstance. You don't say whether or not your political views were aligned before the referendum so it might just be an extension of existing differences. If there is love in the relationship that's more important than distant politics. Ban political discussions from the home for a period of time if it's getting too heated.

title: My husband’s boasts are worse since Brexit – and I can’t stand it | Dear Mariella | Life and style
content: You've been with him for 30 years - and make him sound awful. Perhaps he is. But something has meant you have been together for so long. The answer to that question will surely resolve your current dillema.

title: My husband’s boasts are worse since Brexit – and I can’t stand it | Dear Mariella | Life and style
content: Relationships don't require equal rights. Just rights. It is perfectly possible to have a happy relationship where one partner accepts that the other is dominant. In fact, until recent times, that seems to be how human society worked.

title: We must hope that Europe doesn’t give in to exasperation with Britain | Andrew Rawnsley | Opinion
content: Public policy is not made in a vacuum, the various interest groups push and pull on governments. France expects to suck up a lot of the banking and industrial jobs lost because of brexit and is therefore quite relaxed about a British crash out. Americans see a way into lucrative nhs work and agricultural produce sales and are therefore actively encouraging crash out. Melrose have just shown how it is going to be in brexit Britain.

title: We must hope that Europe doesn’t give in to exasperation with Britain | Andrew Rawnsley | Opinion
content: Why should Europe help us? As with Game of Thrones, Brexit is a white Anglo Saxon fantasy. The real world that most of us actually live in is a much more complicated place. Only a hard, no deal Brexit will force us to confront this fantasy and delusion of Anglo Saxon making. Painfully, for most of us.

title: We must hope that Europe doesn’t give in to exasperation with Britain | Andrew Rawnsley | Opinion

title: We must hope that Europe doesn’t give in to exasperation with Britain | Andrew Rawnsley | Opinion
content: They’ll probably rightly insist on a long extension which would be the most sensible approach. The idea that the Tories who have wasted years arguing with themselves could get this sorted by June, is fanciful. This will likely drag on for years until a second referendum becomes unavoidable.

title: We must hope that Europe doesn’t give in to exasperation with Britain | Andrew Rawnsley | Opinion
content:
It would not be a good look for the EU to effectively eject the UK without a deal, even if that was almost entirely the UK’s fault.
The EU is not ejecting the UK. The UK has stuck two fingers up to the European project, despite having one concessions prior to the referendum, and effectively (to quote that repugnant toad Mark Francois) said 'up yours' to its former EU partners. I think it's clear where responsibility lies, and I think you can drop the 'almost' from your sentence above.

title: We must hope that Europe doesn’t give in to exasperation with Britain | Andrew Rawnsley | Opinion
content:
We must hope that Europe doesn’t give in to exasperation with Britain
On the contrary, the UK needs to leave on Friday, with hopefully France and others vetoing any further extension.
The UK is at the limits of enduring damaging uncertainty, with many companies spending millions on extra stock and procedures, in preparing for a immanent no-deal situation, whilst simultaneously having new contracts deferred.
Only to find that our politicians are now playing games and creating more uncertainty that is now being indefinitely prolonged, which will be far more damaging than a no-deal, that at least will allow everyone to proceed on a known basis.
The fact is, the UK and its people can cope with any definite known scenario, but will not be able to cope with indefinitely prolonging uncertainty, and neither will the EU.
And neither will UK democracy.

title: We must hope that Europe doesn’t give in to exasperation with Britain | Andrew Rawnsley | Opinion
content:
"We must hope that Europe doesn’t give in to exasperation with Britain
The EU would want nothing more that the UK to stay. All this hyperbole about the patience and benevolent EU is just spin by you Andrew.
The EU we are told are ready for a no deal so they should just do it. However, the EU being ready and member states being ready are two different things.

title: The time to sow is now | Allan Jenkins | Life and style
content: Good Morning Allan. Thanks again for a good article and advice. I will be planting runner beans after having a break for a year. Planting Firestorm and Polestar for the first time. We always get results where we are in the West Midlands. We also plant nasturtium to deter blackfly from the runner beans and it seems to work.

title: The time to sow is now | Allan Jenkins | Life and style
content: Mine are in tubs too, and the strawberries in hanging baskets - I find it confuses the birds and puts them beyond the reach of the most persistent of slugs. I’m also East Midlands, it’s a chilly morning here near the coast.

title: The time to sow is now | Allan Jenkins | Life and style
content:
The last of the bulbs are going out today - I’m rather late with the echinacea, but I’m sure it won’t realise we are outside of March now. Peonies to pop in, and Mr Katt to bribe to finish edging the beds, and plant up the new raspberry canes.
Vegetable wise, the tomatoes and peppers are up, and close to being ready to transplant under cloches, and the raised beds prepped and reading for the salads. Early potatoes are just peeping through, and will be moulded up today; the strawberries are going great guns, as are the framberries and pineberries we are trying out for the first time. Lingonberries and blueberries are budding, and the tayberry and blackberry covered in leaves.
I love this time of year, so full of life and promise, the spring and summer stretching out before us, and the garden alive with birds and other wildlife.

title: Screening out Netflix is the real danger to future of film | Film | The Guardian
content:
T here’s still something sacred about the communal experience of the cinema. Sitting in a dark room with a group of strangers and experiencing something together – loud, up-close, and on an enormous screen – remains a timeless pleasure that should be preserved. As a critic, but also as a moviegoer, I worry about this. But misplaced fear and cynicism that streaming platforms will be the cause of the cinema’s decline worries me, too.
“I love Netflix, but fuck Netflix,” said Dame Helen Mirren last week, not mincing her words at the CinemaCon conference in Las Vegas. “There’s nothing like sitting in a cinema.” The British actress was echoing the sentiments of filmmaker Steven Spielberg who, back in February , declared he was “a firm believer that movie theatres need to be around forever”. Netflix, in his eyes, is a threat to that future, discouraging subscribers from going to the cinema by giving them the chance to watch the platform’s original content in their living rooms.
Both Mirren and Spielberg’s comments are revealing of anxieties about alternative models of funding, distributing and watching films. In the same way that, 12 years ago, sceptics were worried that the Amazon Kindle would throw sales of paper books into jeopardy, some members of the film industry are worried about the impact of streaming platforms such as Netflix on the box office, and the wider film culture. In fact, in 2018 the print book market in the UK actually increased, with about 190.9m physical books sold. They have found a way to coexist.
Facebook Twitter Pinterest Roma was released by Netflix and won three Oscars. Photograph: Carlos Somonte/AP
Similarly, Alfonso Cuarón’s Netflix-backed Roma showed that, just because a film can be watched at home, it doesn’t mean lots of people won’t still choose to pay to see it at the cinema. The film made approximately $4m at the international box office during its 15-week run. That’s considerably less than you might expect for a film of its prestige had it been released solely in cinemas, but it’s not exactly a pittance either.
Spielberg, however, doesn’t seem to see things this way. In the run-up to this year’s Oscars, Netflix cannily arranged limited theatrical releases for titles such as the Coen Brothers’ The Ballad of Buster Scruggs and Cuarón’s Roma , simultaneously adding them to its own online platform, therefore qualifying them for awards consideration while also serving subscribers. The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences states that to be eligible for an Oscar a film must play in cinemas, and cannot run on television – or, I suppose, on a streaming platform – before its theatrical debut.But to its credit Netflix is complying with Ampas rules. And it was worth it: Roma won three Oscars.
Spielberg’s furrowed brow suggests a panicked lack of faith that the medium of film can transcend how it is watched
But Spielberg, who is an Ampas board member, appears to be determined to avoid this happening again.
According to Variety , he is lobbying for a rule change that would make films that adopt this release model (known as “day-and-date”) ineligible for Oscar nominations, insisting instead on a longer window between a film’s arrival in cinemas and its streaming debut.
Never mind the fact that many Academy voters rely on “for consideration screeners”, watched on – wait for it – their televisions; the main problem with a restriction like this is that it would also hurt indie distributors, many of whom are already struggling to compete with larger studios. These rules would further narrow the type of film that is celebrated.
Spielberg’s furrowed brow suggests to me a moral conservatism – a panicked lack of faith that the medium of film itself can transcend the device on which it is watched.
Facebook Twitter Pinterest Director Steven Spielberg wants films such as Roma banned from the Oscars. Photograph: Mondadori Portfolio/Getty
In an interview with ITV News last year, he argued that “once you commit to a television format, you’re a TV movie”, insisting that those titles should receive Emmys, not Oscars . Does Spielberg think that watching a film on a TV or a tablet changes its content? The fetishisation of the cinema space is its own problem.
Besides the obvious arguments to be made for streaming platforms’ accessibility (most people don’t live near an independent cinema) and affordability (a monthly subscription is often cheaper than the average cinema ticket), it’s worth considering the kinds of films – and filmmakers – Netflix Originals is backing. From work by Steven Soderbergh, David Fincher and Dee Rees to Martin Scorsese, Nicole Holofcener, Alex Garland and Alice Rohrwacher, Netflix as both a funder and a distributor is putting its money behind projects that consolidate the very auteurism the Oscars claim to celebrate. To exclude these filmmakers from the Oscar race to prove a point seems both petty and pointless.
On the other hand, if this doesn’t come to pass, the implications for companies such as HBO, Amazon and Apple, as well as Netflix, are exciting. Were the Academy less resistant to the way the industry is changing, smaller, riskier films from distinctive but lesser-known voices like Jennifer Fox’s HBO-backed Sundance hit The Tale or Dee Rees’s under-seen Netflix film Mudbound might enter the Oscar race. More people would have seen them, and the culture of film would expand, rather than shrink.

title: Gabriel Jesus fires Manchester City past Brighton and into FA Cup final
content:
Having time to digest the game, I think Man C still have some wooden leg players.
At the interval I think Guardiola told his players to slow down, play the ball to each other (so call rondo) and hit Brighton on the break. It did not work because Mendy, Otamendi et al are not comfortable with the ball, they made easy mistakes, losing the ball without being challenged.
That gave Brighton the chance to equalize Man C made them good, they have big, well build players good in the air which make corners dangerous.
Now if you give Barca players the same orders the opposition will never get the ball, they are all experts of the rondo, it is part of their DNA, look at sequences when Barca get hold of the ball in their own pen area, short accurate passes, no bloody hoofing, just calm constructive play. Despite being surrounded by opposition players.
Alright, Barca have played this kind of football for decades so it may be unjust to compare the two teams but since Pep is the current manager it is hard for a Barca fan not to do so.
Another thing which annoys me. What the f**k is the tiny Gabriel Jesus doing in his own pen area when the opposition have a corner? Just position yourself in the center circle so your defenders have someone to pass the ball to when they get hold of it.

title: Back from the dead: could Tiger really win a fifth Masters Green Jacket? | Sport
content:
Tiger's swing is less important (only 34 shots in a round at Augusta) than his ability to hole putts and get up and down when it's essential. In the past he almost never failed.
He will have to be leading after 3 rounds to have a chance.

title: Back from the dead: could Tiger really win a fifth Masters Green Jacket? | Sport
content: Will he win? No.

title: James Corden as Mr Darcy is more likely than a fat British politician taking high office | Catherine Bennett | Opinion
content: I weighed 18 stone and always felt sorry for myself and blamed others . Then I got my arse into gear literally and am now a trim 12 stone. It’s not rocket science to lose weight and There are no excuses for those that don’t try to .

title: James Corden as Mr Darcy is more likely than a fat British politician taking high office | Catherine Bennett | Opinion
content: Too much weight is a scourge on modern society and has long-term health impacts. However, fat-shaming is counter productive, and the obsession with body image an equally unhealthy trend. Despite all of this, it is my opinion that even if Boris Johnson was to lose more than half his body weight and spend hours a day in the gym toning up, he would still be a stupid, ignorant, immature and feckless waste of British taxpayers' money, and a detriment to good government and a healthy democracy.

title: James Corden as Mr Darcy is more likely than a fat British politician taking high office | Catherine Bennett | Opinion
content: Sadly, there's no evidence that slimming for politicians affects the fat between their ears.

title: James Corden as Mr Darcy is more likely than a fat British politician taking high office | Catherine Bennett | Opinion
content: Yes how dare these people try and improve their physical health? And then suggest that they feel better for it? Outrageous. Lets sneer at their efforts. Great article well done.

title: James Corden as Mr Darcy is more likely than a fat British politician taking high office | Catherine Bennett | Opinion
content: Hopefully Boris will not become PM not because he is overweight but because he is an overweight, unprincipled, self-serving, serial liar.

title: James Corden as Mr Darcy is more likely than a fat British politician taking high office | Catherine Bennett | Opinion
content:
Maybe, instead of endless divisions and mindless discussions in the parliament, each party should designate one chubby politician who will then be locked in a house and forced to lose weight?
Like a cruel(er) version of Big Brother, let's call it Thin Brother / Sister.
The winner would set course of this country for the next year.

title: James Corden as Mr Darcy is more likely than a fat British politician taking high office | Catherine Bennett | Opinion
content:
So, people prefer to watch fit, healthy good-looking actors on the big screen.
Is that really news?

title: James Corden as Mr Darcy is more likely than a fat British politician taking high office | Catherine Bennett | Opinion
content: "celebrity wit"? He's a celebrity so this is 75 per cent true

title: James Corden as Mr Darcy is more likely than a fat British politician taking high office | Catherine Bennett | Opinion
content: It's ok, he can work out in the prison gym when he's eventually indicted over the garden bridge heist.

title: James Corden as Mr Darcy is more likely than a fat British politician taking high office | Catherine Bennett | Opinion
content: The comment about us not expecting Corbyn to start reading books after all this time is a bit odd. From interviews with him, he seems more well-read than most.

title: James Corden as Mr Darcy is more likely than a fat British politician taking high office | Catherine Bennett | Opinion
content: Loosing 7 stone is just good health management. If you can shed that much your life is dominated by excess weight and the deleterious effects of same.

title: James Corden as Mr Darcy is more likely than a fat British politician taking high office | Catherine Bennett | Opinion
content: Because she describes James Corden as a 'wit'.

title: James Corden as Mr Darcy is more likely than a fat British politician taking high office | Catherine Bennett | Opinion
content: See what your sister has to say about Darcy, Kitty.
